title: "problemMatcher": "$msCompile" in tasks.json no longer properly matches problems.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 
- OS Version: 

Steps to Reproduce:

Add this to tasks:

    {
      "type": "shell",
      "label": "dotnet: build",
      "detail": "Builds the Entire Solution",
      "command": "dotnet",
      "args": [
        "build",
        "${workspaceFolder}",
        "/property:GenerateFullPaths=true",
        "/consoleloggerparameters:NoSummary"
      ],
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      },
      "problemMatcher":  "$msCompile"      
    },
Create code with an error

then press CTRL+SHIFT+B

Make sure you have no problems detected before you do this.

It won't show the errors in problems.

And if you do this:

    {
      "type": "shell",
      "label": "dotnet: build",
      "detail": "Builds the Entire Solution",
      "command": "dotnet",
      "args": [
        "build",
        "${workspaceFolder}",
        "/property:GenerateFullPaths=true",
        "/consoleloggerparameters:NoSummary"
      ],
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      },
      "problemMatcher": {
        "owner": "msbuild",
        "source": "msbuild",
        "fileLocation": "absolute",
        "pattern": {
          "regexp": "^(.*)\\((\\d+),(\\d+)\\):\\s+(error|warning)\\s+(\\w+)\\d+:\\s+(.*)$",
          "file": 1,
          "line": 2,
          "column": 3,
          "severity": 4,
          "code": 5,
          "message": 6
        }
      }
    },

Which AI generates to fix it, it does fix it, but when you fix the error in the file, the problems don't update automatically, you have to rebuild to see them updated unlike Rider and VS.net.


Expected Behavior
Should automatically update on the entire solution on build with just a single line in the tasks.json.
Should have documentation on how to setup tasks.json
Should automatically update when files are fixed in source.

Environment Information
Windows 11 Latest
VS Code latest public
C# Dev Kit latest public.

Related here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-dotnettools/issues/2300#issuecomment-3268369347

title: agent hangs when terminal opens webbrowser (e.g. playwright HTML viewer)

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
**Problem**: I use `playwright` test and the default configuration that's generated pops open a Browser window (and blocks the command from finishing until Ctrl+C) whenever a test fails (so long as it [doesn't detect it's running in CI])(https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/ed7b48efab8c433b1618820d1d4692cd1a14d1cd/packages/playwright/src/reporters/html.ts#L139-L150):

```
npm run test
```

Since I'm in Agent mode, this isn't helpful. I just want the agent to view the output in the console and fix the tests without having me review the HTML report.

**Possible Solutions**: Whenever Copilot launches a terminal, have it set an environvement variable `VSCODE_COPILOT_TERMINAL_SESSION` (modulo naming), so authors of libraries can modify default behavior e.g.:

* don't open interactive windows
* change reporting format to be more LLM friendly
* others?

/cc:

* @Chuxel - this would also be helpful in hosted Copilot. The browser popping open is not an issue, but I could see library authors conditionally changing output formats etc.
* @Tyriar, @meganrogge 
* @pavelfeldman, @dgozman - would PW actually want this behavior? I know I'd want it as a user.

title: mssql extension VS code, missing search widget from Azure Data Studio.
body: HI All I'm moving from Azure Data Studio to VS Code( it'll be retired next FEB), it's a great tool however I really miss the easy way to look for sql server objects in an entire database like I used to in ADS( img 1 ), right click and work on it. I cannot find this feature in mssql extension. VS code has some filter buttons for specific folders, but it's not the same, you need to click it on the folder you want instead of search on the entire database as ADS. ADS VS Code I think it'll be a great add-on for mssql extension. Regards!!

title: Auto mode doesn't work with responses API

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

body:
Why does AutoChatEndpoint override `makeChatRequest2`, but the other methods use `this._wrappedEndpoint`? This means that we didn't get a chance to disable `ignoreStatefulMarker`. 

This is exactly the problem that I tried to explain earlier with having multiple disconnected methods that all need to be aligned in order to handle a request using the right API.

title: Code adjustments made by Copilot wont show in the editor or on disk.
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->


After working for a while (at least 10 hours) in a new VS Code window with only the 3 extensions (see below) the Copilot Chat Code adjustments wont show in the editor or on disk like before. Manual edits still save normally.

Environment:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
- VS Code Version: see below
- Active extensions: GitHub Copilot, GitHub Copilot Chat, PHP Intelephense
- OS Version: Windows 11 Home
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): happened in GPT 4.1 and GPT 5.

Steps to Reproduce:
Open a project in VS Code and a file (e.g. .gitignore).
Asking Copilot to fill the .gitignore.
Expected: the suggestion appears in the editor and is saved to disk.
Actual: the editor still displays the old content and the file on disk remains unchanged.

Key observations
Disabling GitHub Copilot Chat (or GitHub Copilot) eliminates the issue locally (A/B test result) in my last test.

Developer Console / extension host logs showed messages such as:
"potential listener LEAK detected"
"Chat model provider for vendor <vendor> is already registered."

Sanitized console/exthost excerpt (replace with 5–10 lines):
[Extension Host] potential listener LEAK detected
[Exthost] Chat model provider for vendor openai is already registered.
[Exthost] Chat model provider for vendor openrouter is already registered.
[Exthost] Chat model provider for vendor azure is already registered.

What I’m providing:
This single text (no logs).

Request to Support:
Please check for a possible race/registration bug in the Extension Host related to Chat provider registration.
Please advise what minimal additional logs/traces you need and the preferred secure channel for sharing them.

Additional details (filled where available from local env snapshot):
- Exact VS Code version and build: 1.104.0 (x64) — inferred as Stable from the installed build
- Exact extension versions: GitHub Copilot 1.368.0, GitHub Copilot Chat 0.31.0
- Reproduced on: Stable (inferred)
- Reproduced in a clean window with other extensions disabled: so far not tested
- Occurs in remote workspaces (WSL/SSH/Container) or only local: local in initial tests 
- Auto Save enabled: yes
- Did you manually save after accepting the suggestion: in troubleshooting I used manual saves and commits to capture state;  during the failing case I did not save manually, but later tried to save manually without effect
- File type(s) where the issue occurs: no specific type
- Acceptance method used: Clicked "Keep" even though no change appeared
- Does `git status` show the file as changed immediately after accepting suggestion: no
- Does closing+reopening the file or Reload Window temporarily fix the problem: only in combination with disabling Copilot Chat the issue was removed. After enabling and reloading the window it worked, but Copilot can't pinpoint the issue.


-- End --

title: Fix ambiguous description for chat.tools.edits.autoApprove setting
body:
The description for the `chat.tools.edits.autoApprove` setting was misleading about how pattern matching works, causing confusion for users trying to understand the behavior.

## Problem

The previous description stated:
> "Files are matched against the glob patterns in the order they are specified."

This suggested a first-match-wins approach, but the default configuration would make this behavior nonsensical:

```json
{
  "**/*": true,
  "**/.vscode/*.json": false,
  "**/.git/**": false
}
```

If patterns were processed in order with first-match-wins, the `**/*` pattern would match everything and the subsequent deny patterns would never be reached, making them useless.

## Solution

Updated the description to clarify that pattern matching follows a deny-takes-precedence model, consistent with the terminal auto approve setting:

> "Set to `true` to automatically approve edits to matching files, `false` to always require explicit approval. If a file matches multiple patterns, patterns set to `false` take precedence over patterns set to `true`."

This makes the default configuration logical:
- `src/hello.ts` → matches `**/*` (true) → **auto-approved** ✅
- `.vscode/settings.json` → matches both `**/*` (true) and `**/.vscode/*.json` (false) → **requires approval** ❌ (false wins)

## Impact

- **No functional changes** - this is purely a documentation fix
- **Eliminates user confusion** about how the setting actually works
- **Consistent** with terminal auto approve behavior where "a `false` overrides a `true`" (as noted by @Tyriar)
- **Makes the default configuration self-explanatory**

Fixes #[issue_number]

title: Support tool calling responses for @github requests via platform agent in VSCode

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

## Problem
- When using the `@github` tag in VSCode, it currently calls the platform agent in CAPI using **legacy function calling**.  
- Legacy function calling is not supported on the CAPI side for **Sonnet models**.  
- We are also seeing issues with the **GPT-5 family** of models since the role `function` is no longer supported.
- Maintaining function calling flows separately adds overhead and is not future-proof.

Ref issue: https://github.com/github/copilot-experiences/issues/7475

## Request
Add client-side support in VSCode for **responses with tool calls**.  
Tool calling is the preferred method going forward, and this change would eliminate the need to maintain deprecated function calling pathways.  

## Notes
- For the platform agent, **tool calls are handled within the agent itself**.  
- This should not require additional client-side tool calling logic beyond parsing and passing through tool call responses.  

## Benefits
- Future-proofing against deprecation of function calling.  
- Compatibility with **Sonnet** and **GPT-5 family** models.  
- Reduced maintenance burden by aligning with current standards for LLM interactions.

title: Allow changing default extensions installation path via settings
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, VS Code installs extensions into the default user directory:

-  Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.vscode\extensions
-  macOS/Linux: ~/.vscode/extensions

While it’s possible to change the extensions folder using the --extensions-dir flag or by creating a symbolic link, these workarounds are not very user-friendly and require extra setup.

For users with limited space on their system drive, or those who want to:

-  Keep extensions on a different drive (e.g., D:)
-  Manage extensions separately for portability or backup
-  Standardize paths across multiple machines

…it would be much more convenient if VS Code supported a setting in settings.json to change the default extensions installation path.

**Current Behavior:**

- Extensions are always installed into the default .vscode/extensions directory unless --extensions-dir is manually specified at launch.
- No persistent or UI-based way to change the location.

**Proposed Solution:**

Add a new user setting, for example:

"extensions.installPath": "D:\\VSCodeExtensions"


VS Code would then install and load extensions from this directory automatically.

**Benefits:**

- Reduces reliance on command-line flags or symlinks
- Easier setup for non-technical users
- Helps users with small system drives
- Makes extension management and backup more flexible

title: Extension host crashes repeatedly after updating to VS Code 1.104.0 with GitHub Copilot enabled

labels.name: freeze-slow-crash-leak
labels.description: VS Code crashing, performance, freeze and memory leak issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body: hi. #Descrição em Português Após atualizar o Visual Studio Code para a versão 1.104.0 (user setup), as extensões começaram a falhar exibindo a seguinte mensagem (print em anexo): ` O host de extensão foi encerrado inesperadamente 3 vezes nos últimos 5 minutos. ` Detalhes do Ambiente ``` Versão: 1.104.0 (user setup) Commit: f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260 Data: 2025-09-10T06:46:18.035Z Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12342881 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 SO: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 ``` ##Comportamento Observado - O erro ocorre repetidamente, encerrando o host de extensão várias vezes em poucos minutos. - A mensagem aparece mesmo após reiniciar o VS Code. ##Extensões Relacionadas (GitHub Copilot) ``` Identificador: github.copilot-chat Versão: 0.31.0 Última Atualização: 2025-09-12 09:45:21 Identificador: github.copilot Versão: 1.368.0 Última Atualização: 2025-09-12 11:16:46 ``` ##Solução Temporária - Desativar as extensões do GitHub Copilot ou - Reverter o VS Code para a versão 1.103.0. # English Description After updating Visual Studio Code to version 1.104.0 (user setup), extensions started failing and show the following message (screenshot attached): ` The extension host terminated unexpectedly 3 times in the last 5 minutes. ` ## Environment Details ``` Version: 1.104.0 (user setup) Commit: f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260 Date: 2025-09-10T06:46:18.035Z Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12342881 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 ``` ## Observed Behavior - The error occurs repeatedly, causing the extension host to crash several times within minutes. - It persists even after restarting VS Code. ##Related Extensions (GitHub Copilot) ``` Identifier: github.copilot-chat Version: 0.31.0 Last Updated: 2025-09-12 09:45:21 Identifier: github.copilot Version: 1.368.0 Last Updated: 2025-09-12 11:16:46 ``` ## Temporary Workaround - Disable the GitHub Copilot extensions - Downgrade VS Code to version 1.103.0. Sorry, but I used artificial intelligence to transcribe the issue into English.

title: VS Code becomes uninstalled when I shut down my machine
body:
Type: Bug steps: 1.) Close VS Code 2.) Windows button >> Power Button >> Shutdown 3.) Turn machine back on When machine boots up, VS Code is no longer installed. I suspect it is trying to update when I close VS Code before I shutdown but there is no indication it is doing anything. Even if I wait a few minutes, sometimes it still will uninstall itself. title: Use actual command labels in accessibility help instead of duplicate localized strings
body:
Fixes the issue raised by @roblourens in #257355 where accessibility help was using separate localized strings for command labels instead of referencing the actual command labels defined in the action classes.

## Problem

The accessibility help for chat editing commands was creating duplicate localized strings:

```typescript
// Duplicate localization in accessibility help
content.push(localize('chatEditing.viewChanges', '- View Changes{0}.', '<keybinding:chatEditing.viewChanges>'));
content.push(localize('chatEditing.viewPreviousEdits', '- View Previous Edits{0}.', '<keybinding:chatEditing.viewPreviousEdits>'));

// While the actual commands already had their own labels
export class ChatEditingShowChangesAction {
    static readonly LABEL = localize('chatEditing.viewChanges', 'View All Edits');
}
export class ViewPreviousEditsAction {
    static readonly Label = localize('chatEditing.viewPreviousEdits', 'View Previous Edits');
}
```

This approach had several issues:
- **Translation inconsistency**: Same command could have different labels in different languages
- **Maintenance burden**: Labels had to be kept in sync manually
- **Syntax errors**: One line was missing the `localize()` function call
- **Incorrect references**: Referenced non-existent `chatEditing.viewAllEdits` command

## Solution

Now the accessibility help imports the actual command action classes and uses their existing label properties:

```typescript
import { ChatEditingShowChangesAction, ViewPreviousEditsAction } from '../chatEditing/chatEditingActions.js';

// Use actual command labels
content.push(localize('chatEditing.viewChanges.withLabel', '- {0}{1}.', ChatEditingShowChangesAction.LABEL, '<keybinding:chatEditing.viewChanges>'));
content.push(localize('chatEditing.viewPreviousEdits.withLabel', '- {0}{1}.', ViewPreviousEditsAction.Label, '<keybinding:chatEditing.viewPreviousEdits>'));
```

## Benefits

- ✅ **Single source of truth**: Command labels defined once in action classes
- ✅ **Translation consistency**: Same labels appear in command palette and accessibility help
- ✅ **Reduced maintenance**: Only need to update labels in one place
- ✅ **Fixed syntax errors**: Removed malformed line and incorrect command references
- ✅ **Follows VS Code patterns**: Aligns with how other parts of the codebase handle command labels

The accessibility help will now always display the exact same command labels that users see in the Command Palette, ensuring a consistent experience across all VS Code interfaces.

title: Fix Model Picker accessibility: Make hover tooltip information available to screen readers
body:
## Problem

Screen reader users could not access the additional context information (like "Variable: 0x") that appears in tooltips when hovering over models in the Model Picker dropdown. This created an accessibility gap where sighted users had access to important model details that were completely unavailable to users relying on assistive technologies.

As shown in the screenshot, when hovering over "GPT-4o" in the Model Picker, sighted users see additional information like "Variable: 0x", but screen readers would only announce "GPT-4o" without any of the contextual details.

## Solution

Modified the `getAriaLabel` function in `ActionList` to include tooltip and description information in the accessibility label. Now when screen readers encounter a Model Picker item, they will announce both the model name and the additional context information.

**Before:**
- Screen reader announces: "GPT-4o"

**After:**  
- Screen reader announces: "GPT-4o, Variable: 0x"

## Changes

- Enhanced the accessibility provider in `src/vs/platform/actionWidget/browser/actionList.ts`
- Added logic to include tooltip information when it differs from the label
- Added logic to include description information when it differs from both tooltip and label  
- Ensured no duplication of identical information
- Maintained existing behavior for all other cases

This change affects all Action Widget dropdowns throughout VS Code, improving accessibility across the entire application while specifically addressing the Model Picker issue.

## Testing

The fix has been verified to:
- ✅ Include tooltip information in screen reader announcements
- ✅ Avoid duplicating identical information  
- ✅ Handle edge cases (separators, missing tooltips, etc.)
- ✅ Maintain backward compatibility
- ✅ Work across all Action Widget implementations

Fixes accessibility gap where hover information was unavailable to screen reader users.

- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Debian Linux rodete

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the welcome page from the help menu
2. Cycle through views with F6 (or shift F6)

At the point where focus should jump from the side bar to the editor, rather than jumping to the welcome page, the focus stays on the sidebar. (In the case of Shift F6, it gets stuck on the panel.)

I think that it should either focus the welcome view, or skip it and jump to the panel.

Configure a custom agent with Gemini Pro using my own API key. Ask the agent to perform an action (e.g., edit a file). The model only returns plain text and fails with Invalid JSON for tool call. # Expected Behavior The Gemini Pro agent with my own API key should behave the same as the built-in Gemini Pro agent available in the agent selector: It should support tool calls (code edits, inline explanations, etc.).
